metadata.title: Wound healing properties of PVA/ starch /chitosan hydrogel membranes with nano Zinc oxide as antibacterial wound dressing material

sections.text:
In this work, hydrogel membranes were developed based on poly vinyl alcohol (PVA), starch (St), and chitosan (Cs) hydrogels with nano Zinc oxide (nZnO). PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes were prepared by freezing-thawing cycles, and the aqueous PVA/St solutions were prepared by dissolving PVA in distilled water. After the dissolution of PVA, starch was mixed, and the mixture was stirred. Then, chitosan powder was added into acetic acid, and the mixture was stirred to form a chitosan solution. Subsequently, Cs, St and PVA solutions were blended together to form a homogeneous PVA/St/Cs ternary blend solution.Measurement of Equilibrium Swelling Ratio (ESR),Water Vapor Transmission Test (WVTR), mechanical properties, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), MTT [3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2, 5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide] assay, D ow
nl oa
de d
by [
antibacterial studies, in vivo wound healing effect and histopathology of the hydrogel membranes were then performed. The examination revealed that the hydrogel membranes were more effective as a wound dressing in the early stages of wound healing and that the gel could be used in topic applications requiring a large spectrum of antibacterial activity; namely, as a bandage for wound dressing.
Keywords: Chitosan, Hydrogel membrane, Poly vinyl alcohol, Starch, Wound Dressing

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Wound is a kind of injury happeningbecauseof burn, surgery, diabetes, trauma, etc. [1]. An ideal wound dressing should have flexibility, adequate mechanical strength, and tear resistance; moreover, it should not stick onto the wounds [2], and should also be able to absorb wound exudates from the wound surface [3]. The dressing should not only serve as a barrier against microbes, but it shouldalso prevent the growth of microorganisms on the wound surface [4]. In addition, it should be porous in nature so that it can easily let the gaseous exchange in and out of the wound surface [3].All dressing materials are made from natural or synthetic materials [5–10], whichhave both advantages and disadvantages. Most of them have had good effects on normal wound healing; however, their effects on chronic or diabetic foot ulcers have not been studied yet [6, 7]. Moreover, they do not generallyhave adequate mechanical strength and flexibility [8], some of them lack blood-clotting ability and some have no or little antibacterial activity. Non-biodegradability is another problem with these materials; apart from that, most of them are expensive, too. With regard to all these factors, it is necessary to develop a wound dressing material that has all the ideal requirements [9]. PVA hydrogels have already been used for a large number of pharmaceutical and biomedical applications [10]because apart from their ease of processing, their advantages such as biocompatibility, non-carcinogenicity, bio-adhesiveness, nonD ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er
2 01
7
toxicity, excellent film forming and transparency make them good candidates to serve as biomaterials. PVA possesses a simple chemical structure, and a simple reaction can chemically modify it. At the same time, PVA gels have a high degree of swelling in water or biological fluids in addition to an elastic or rubbery nature [11], which makes it capable of simulating natural tissues and which can be suitably accepted in the body. Semi-crystalline PVA gels were prepared by exposing a PVA aqueous solution to repetitive freezing–thawing cycles. This induced crystallization and led to a network structure that served as physical crosslinking sites in the network. This method is regarded as the best and the preferred one for obtaining physically crosslinked PVA hydrogel without using traditional toxic chemical crosslinking agents [12]. Among these natural biopolymers, and due to its great crosslinking ability in the presence of abundant hydroxyl (OH) groups, starch has proved to be a good precursor material for preparing hydrogels. However, its hydrophilic nature and poor mechanical properties have hampered the development of unmodified starch as a stable hydrogel [13, 14]. Hence, to enhance its mechanical properties, different biodegradable synthetic polymers like poly(vinyl alcohol), (PVA) and poly(caprolactone), poly(lactic acid) (PLA), and PCL have been mixed with starch molecules [15,16]. Chitosan, a cationic polysaccharide, is obtained by alkaline deacetylation of chitin that is the principal exoskeletal component in crustaceans. With a collection of properties like biodegradability, fat binding capacity, water binding capacity, biocompatibility, nontoxicity, bioactivity, and antifungal activity, chitosan and its modified counterparts have had many applications in tissue engineering, medicine, agriculture, cosmetics, biochemical separation systems, biomaterials and drug controlled release systems [17-23]. At neutral pH, chitin has no antibacterial activity because of lack of free –NH2 groups [24]; therefore, it is essential to add some external agents so that it can possess the antibacterial activity. To attain this property, nZnO was selected since it is known to possess antibacterial activity and it is already being used in many D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7
cosmetic materials [25]. Previous studies showed that in the size scale less than 100 nm and at the appropriate concentration, nZnO possesses potent antibacterial activity with no negative effect on normal cells [26]. Moreover, zinc ions released from ZnO can enhance keratinocyte migration towards the wound site, thus promoting its healing [27, 28]. In this work, composite bandages were developedbased on poly (vinyl alcohol), starch, chitosan hydrogels with nZnO, and they were evaluated in detail. With regard to the fact that bipartite and tripartite compounds of[29-35] and [36-45] PVA/Cs and PVA/Cs/nZnO [46-49]have been investigated in different studies, in this study, how wound healing occurs with all four materials present is dealt with.
2. Materials and methods 2.1. Materials Chemicals, starch (ST) (Sigma-Aldrich), poly (vinyl alcohol) (PVA) (mole mass, 72000 gr/mol) (Merck), chitosan(Cs) with a 90% degree of deacetylation and 122.400 g mol-1 average molecular weight(Sigma Chemical Company (St. Louis, USA) ), acetic acid (glacial, 99-100%) and Zinc oxide nano-particles (nZnO) (Aldrich, 20 nm avg. part .size) were purchased and used without further purification.
2.2. Preparation of hydrogel membranes
2.2.1 Preparation of PVA/St/Cs solution
PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes were prepared by freezing-thawing (F–T) cycle in accordance with the procedure [30]. First, the aqueous PVA/St solutions were prepared by dissolving 15%(w/v) PVA in distilled water at 80oC for about 6h. After PVA was dissolved, 2.5%(w/v) starch was mixed, and the mixture was stirred for about 120 min.Different contents of chitosan (4%, 7%, 10% dry weight of PVA/St polymers)(w/v) powder were

dissolved in 0.1% acetic acid, and the mixture was stirred to form a chitosan solution. Then, Cs, St and PVA solutions were blended together to form a homogeneous PVA/St/Csternaryblend solution.
2.2.2. Preparation of PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes The hydrogel membranes were filled with 0.1% dry weight of PVA/St/Cs polymers (w/v) ZnO nanoparticles [49], and the levels of each component were chosen for the experiment (See Figure 1). By using an ultrasonic homogenizer for 1h, ZnO nanoparticles were dispersed in the matrix. Proper amounts of this mixture were poured in standard disposable polystyrene petri dishes (inside dimension is 84 mm diameter and 12 mm H), followed by freezing at - 20oC for 18h and thawing for 6h at 25oC for three continuous cycles in order to provide mechanically acceptable hydrogel properties for further experiments. Then, the petri dishes were placed on the leveled flat surface, and were dried under atmosphere conditions. After that, the dried hydrogel membranes were peeled away from the polystyrene petri dishes and were stored at 4oC. For further characterizations, all samples were left in deionized water for 72h to extract the leachable sol fraction or unconnected monomer from the polymer matrix. Then, the obtained PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes were frozen in liquid nitrogen for 10min before hydrogel membranes were fractured for SEM investigations.

sections.heading: 2.4. Water vapor transmission test
sections.text:
Water vapor transmission tests were conducted using the JIS 1099A standard method [44]. A round piece of hydrogel membrane was mounted on the mouth of a cup (7cm diameter) containing 50 g of CaCl2, and itwas placed in an incubator of 90% RH at 40oC. The Water Vapor Transmission Rate (WVTR) was determined as follows:    2 12/ 24W WWVTR g m day S     (2)
Where, 1W and 2W are the weights of the whole cup at the first and second hours, respectively, and S represents the transmitting area of the sample.

sections.heading: 2.5. Mechanical properties
sections.text:
Using a tensile test machine (Instron 4464, UK), the tensile strength and breaking elongation of hydrogels were determined. After three F–T cycles, the hydrogel membranes were cut into a specific dog-bone shape (6cm long, 2 cm wide at the ends and 1 cm wide in the middle). In order to determine the maximum load for each matrix [30], the mechanical analysis was performed at a stretching rate of 20mm/min with pre-load of 0.5N. The thickness of the hydrogel membrane was measured with a digital caliper (CD-15CPX, Mitutoyo Co., Japan) before examination [50]. D ow

sections.heading: 2.6. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM)
sections.text: The surface structures of the hydrogel membranes were investigated by Analytical-SEM (type: JEOL, JSM-6360LA, Japan). All images were taken of 3000 magnification at an operating voltage of 15kV, and all the specimens were sputter-coated with gold-caladium alloy in a sputter coater model CS 7620 in 2 min.

sections.heading: 2.7. Cytotoxicity analysis
sections.text:
The MTT [3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide] assay was performed for cytotoxicity analysis of the hydrogel membranes. Cell Krayvtyvbwas prepared from Pasteur Institute in Iran. The Krayvtyvb contained fibroblast cells of human L929 cells, which were cultured in special cell culture flasks after being defrosted. In order to culture these cells, DMEM (Grand Island, NY) along with 100 ml of penicillin (Sigma, USA) and Streptomycin (Sigma, USA) antibiotics was used.In addition to the culture environment, 10% FBS was used to enrich it; then, the cells were counted by neobar lam, and 10,000 cells were placed in each well of 96-cell plates in the form of a layer. For each density of materials to be tested, three wells were allocated for various times; 24h and 48h; and three wells were considered for the control group. In each well of the 96-cell plate for cell culture, 104 fibroblast L929 cells were placed, and after 24h of incubation (CO2 pressure 5%, Humidity 98%, temperature 37 degrees), the surface culture environment was emptied. In order to study the toxicity of samples and their effect on cell growth and reproduction, first, the hydrogel membrane was sterilized using UV ray, and then the extraction process was carried out based on ISO10993-5 standard. A similar volume of the culture environment was also considered as the control. Then, the vitality of cells was studied 24h and 48h after juxtaposition with hydrogel extract using MTT test. To do D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7
this, after the lapse of intended times, the cell culture environments were taken out of the incubator, 1% of the surface volume of cells of MTT was added to each well, and the plate was placed in the incubator for 4h. During the incubation, MTT was formed by a dehydronage succinate system, which is one of the enzymes of mitochondria breathing cycle. The formation and fracture of this loop caused formazan blue crystals, which were easily diagnosed under a microscopewhile being produced. The amount of produced color was directly proportional to the number of cells that were metabolically active. Formazan crystals were not soluble in water, and had tobe changed into a solution by a solvent such as DMSO before chronometry. This liquid color was transmitted to ELISA hydrogel membrane wells, and its absorption was read using ELISA READER at a wavelength of 570 nanometer with reference filter of 620 nanometer, and the optical absorption of wells was statistically judged using ANOVA test. The percentage cell viability of samples, compared to thecontrol, was calculated from the following equation:
  ( ) ( )% 100 ( ) ( )

sections.heading: 2.8. In Vitro Antibacterial Studies
sections.text:
Antimicrobial and antifungal activities of the developed hydrogel membranes were tested by disc diffusion method using E. coli, S. aureus and P. aeruginosa bacteria.They were used to evaluate the antibacterial activity of the prepared hydrogel membranes. Luria-Bertani agar (LB agar) was used as a culturing nutrient source. After isolating E. coli, S. aureus and P. aeruginosa bacteria, half a McFarland was taken from the bacterial colony and was dissolved in the sterile physiology serum. After the preparation of the homogenous solution, it was stirred with a sterile swab, was transmitted to Muller Hinton culture environment, and the culture environment was fully cultured lawn-wise with the swab. After the culture, antibiogram disks, which included synthesized hydrogel membranes, were selected and D ow nl oa de d

placed on the culture environment and were incubated for 24h at 37oC. After 24h, the hydrogel membrane under the light was checked and the diameter of the inhibition was measured with a ruler and they were reported. There was an inhibition around some disks indicating the sensitivity of that bacterium to that disk and was reported sensitive. However, there was no inhibition around some disks. In this case, this bacterium was reported resistant to that disk. The experiments were performed in triplicate and were repeated on at least three separate occasions.

sections.heading: 2.9. Study on animals
sections.text:
This lab study was conducted in accordance with ethical principles approved by institution review board of the University of Isfahan on 42 adult male rats with an approximate weight of 240-280 g. The rats were approximately 4 months old and were taken from the center of experimental animals of the University of Isfahan. They were stored at a temperature of about 27 ° C and a 12-hour darkness cycle in a separate cage. At first, the animals received ketamine (10%) at a dose of 50 mg / kg body weight and zeylerin (2%) at a rate of 5 mg per kg body weight, and they were injected and anesthetized. Then, to produce an open ulcer, the hair behind the animal was shaved with a razor, and the site of the ulcer was disinfected by alcohol. After that, the skin on the back area was marked on the posterior part of the scapula with a dimension of 1 × 1, and then, using scissors and a surgical blade, the entire skin was removed so that the depth of the wound included a derma and a hypoderm, and the wounds were washed with normal saline. In addition, all the wounds were created by a surgeon. The rats were randomly divided into three groups with 7 rats in each group so that the wounds were not treated in any form in the control group (group A). The second group (group B) was treated with hydrogel membrane with a ratio of 15% PVA / 2.5% St / 7% Cs daily, and the rats in thethird group (group C) were treated with a hydrogel membrane with a 15% PVA / 2.5% St / 7% Cs / 0.1% nZnO, and they were dressed daily. Considering the fact that D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er
2 01
7
PVA/starch hydrogel with 7% of chitosan content has better mechanical properties and has higher cell viability compared to samples with 4% and 10% of chitosan, and with regard to the amount of water absorption and suitable water vapor penetration, this hydrogel membrane with and without nZno was used for wound dressing.

seventh, ninth, eleventh and fourteenth days, the rats were anesthetized using ether, and at regular and fixed intervals, related images were taken using a digital camera. The wound size was measured using the software Adobe Photoshop Cs6 [6], and the percentage of wound size was calculated by the following formula:

sections.text:
On the seventeenth and fourteenth days of the experiment, in order to examine the wound histology, the wound healing behind the rats in each of the three groups was cut with a part of the healthy skin around the wound. These tissue samples were stabilized in formalin 10% and then they were dehydrated with alcohol of varying degrees (60% alcohol to absolute alcohol). After that, the molded tissues, having successive sections with a thickness of 5 microns, were

sections.heading: 3.1. Swelling Studies
sections.text:
Due to its water-holding capacity, the swelling capacity of a hydrogel membrane has an important role in antibacterial activity, wound restoration capacity and biomedical application. The hydrogel membranes can absorb a small to medium amount of wound exudate by swelling, which helps the quick restoration of the wound. The hydrogel swelling behavior depends on the nature of the polymer network like the presence of hydrophilic groups, the density of crosslink bond, the elasticity of the polymer network, pH and the temperature of the swelling environment. In this way, each variety in the structure of hydrogel network directly affects its swelling behavior. In any case, an increase in viscosity and the filling of empty spaces or pores by nZnO molecules inside the gel network can stop the water molecules from entering the hydrogel; hence, the more the amount of nZnO, the less the amount of water absorption (Figure 2). In this study, the capacity of swelling of PVA/St/Cs hydrogel membranes and PVA/St/Cs/nZnO has been studied in different intervals. In Figure 2, it was noticed that PVA/St/Cs showed a higher swelling capacity than the PVA/St/Cs/nZnO. The decrease in the swelling capacity was related to the connection of nZnO and electrons of oxygen and hydrogen atoms of hydroxyl groups and amine existing in chitosan/PVA chains, which caused a more crosslink bond in the chain networks. Higher bond in the hydrogel membranes limited the diffusion of water for the swelling. The presence of nZnO caused a decrease in all pores, which was related to the interaction between chitosan, PVA and nZnO. As seen in D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7
Figure 2, with an increase in nZnO content, the amount of swelling was decreased probably due to the fact that nZnO acts as a strengthening substance causing hydration ability of the hydrogel membranes. As a result, the highest amount of swelling was obtained for hydrogel membranes without nZnO content.Moreover, increase in chitosan content in the hydrogel
membrane in Figure 3A remarkably increased the swelling capacity and a similar trend was maintained regarding PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes, which was due to the presence of more hydrophilic groups in the networks. This affected the promotion of swelling characteristic of the hydrogel membranes. In the study conducted on PVA/St/Cs/nZnO, (Figure 3B), it was clarified that all hydrogel membranes had higher water absorbing capacity in an acidic environment than in a basic environment, which is due to the presence of amino groups. The amino group of chitosan is protonated in the acidic environment, and the protonation leads to electrostatic repulsion and separation of hydrogen bonds among polymers and release of macromolecular chains finally leading to an increase in swelling ratio. In a neutral or basic environment, amino groups of chitosan are deprotonated and electrostatic repulsion is decreased leading to a decrease in swelling characteristics. These data showed that the potential of dressings to use as exudate-absorbing wound dressing exists, and infection resulting from exudates is decreased. The high water absorbability of chitosan prevents the collection of liquid on the wound, and decreases the risk of infection.

sections.heading: 3.2. Water vapor transmission test
sections.text:
In Figure 4, the effect of chitosan and nZnO on the rate of water vapor transmission has been illustrated. If the rate of water vapor transmission is high, it will cause the wound surface to get dry; and if it is low, it will cause exudates to be collected, which will delay the treatment trend and increase the risk of bacterial growth. In this article, it is noticed that with an

increase in the amount of chitosan, the rate of water vapor transmission increases. It is noticed that the presence of nZnO prevents the passage of water vapor because of blocking the pores existing in hydrogel. In samples containing nZnO, with an increase in chitosan percentage, the rate of water vapor transmission increases. Dressings should have a suitable capability of liquid absorption and humidity diffusion.

sections.heading: 3.3. Mechanical properties of the hydrogel membranes
sections.text: The effect of chitosan on the tensile strength (Figure 5A) and strain (Figure 5B) in hydrogel membranes was studied. With an increase in chitosan percentage, the tensile strength was decreased; while by adding nZnO, it was increased. Many artificial and natural polymer materials have been developed for the treatment of burn wounds, and limitation in their application is because of their weak mechanical properties and their lower rate in water absorption. In this study, with regard to the results, it is noticed that by adding ZnO to PVA/St/Cs hydrogel membrane, the mechanical properties will increase. As noticed in elongation-Force curve, which is equivalent to Stress-strain curve, in Figure 6(A-C), in a fixed force, with an increase in chitosan percentage, the elongation of the hydrogel membrane is decreased because an increase in chitosan causes an increase in pores in the network, thus decreasing the crosslinking. Moreover, it is noticed that adding nZnO leads to an increase in elongation because nZnO increases the mechanical properties by blocking the pores existing in the hydrogel.

sections.heading: 3.4. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sections.text:
SEM imaging is one of the promising techniques for the topographic study of the prepared samples because it gives important information regarding the shape and size of synthesized
D ow
nl oa
de d
by [
G ot
he nb
ur g
U ni

2: 36
0 8
O ct
ob er
2 01
7
particles. SEM micrographs in Figure 7(A-C), taken from the fracture surface of samples, showed that the starch granules were completely dissolved, and a continuous phase was obtained. Adding Cs in PVA hydrogel in different portions, 4%, 7% and 10%, provides very tiny pores at the structures; and these pores notably increase with increasing Cs contents. In addition, the more the amount of chitosan, the more the porosity of the hydrogel membranes becomes. On the other hand, layered and channeling cross-section-shape structures are noticed at hydrogel membranes. In addition, pores, cracks, and somewhat caves appear after the incorporation of different portions of Cs in cross-section structure of hydrogel membranes. Our results suggest that the entangling between PVAs was reduced by chitosan, which could decrease the network densities because it induced relatively entangled porous sizes and perturbed the stable three dimensional polymer networks. The incorporation of the nZnO onto the hydrogel membranes was also explored in the cross-section image (Figure 7). The small lighted spots present in the cross-section area represent nZnO mobilized onto PVA/St/Cs polymeric matrix, and the nanoparticles can reinforce the polymer if they are properly dispersed. Ultrasonic mixing causes ZnO nanoparticles to be quite uniformly dispersed inside the PVA/St/Cs matrix. The homogeneity and uniform distribution of nZnO onto the polymeric matrix are observed from this image. This micrograph investigates the open pores and cavities that are present inside the hydrogel membranes, acting as host places. Adding nZnO causes a reduction in the porosity of hydrogel membranes, which is due to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonding between nZnO and Cs. This interaction causes the polymer chains of chitosan to be packed together leading to a reduction in porosity.

sections.heading: 3.5. In-vitro cytotoxicity test
sections.text:
Evaluation of cytotoxicity for hydrogels is very important in wound dressing applications. MTT assay is often used to evaluate the in vitro cytotoxicity of polymeric components. This

method is quick and effectivefor testing mitochondrial impairment and correlates quite well with cell proliferation.The cytotoxicity tests through the MTT assay have been used to check the biocompatibility of the material, and the cytotoxicity of hydrogel membranes was analyzed using human dermal fibroblast cells. The effects of hydrogel extracts on L929 cultured human fibroblast cells viability after 24h and 48h incubation are shown in Figure 8. According to GB/T 16886.5-2003 (ISO 10993-5: 1999), samples with cell viability larger than 75% can be considered non-cytotoxic. The MTT assay shows that the synthesized membranes had no effect on the growth of these cells. The viability of the cell still reached above 87%, which indicated that PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membrane extracts were extremely low toxic to L929 fibroblast cells. When nZnO was used, no statistically significant differences were observed in the cell activity in comparison to control, which meant PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membrane extracts were non-toxic to L929 cells. The viability of the cell, after 48h in the presence of all the hydrogel membrane extracts without nZnO, reached 100%, which was probably owing to high cationic charge densities of CS and St. The ability of chitosan to enhance cell attachment and proliferation has been contradictory in both stimulatory and inhibitory effects; however, all the results indicated that all hydrogel membranes could be used as wound dressing for skin regeneration in tissue engineering and other biomedical applications.

sections.heading: 3.6. In Vitro Antibacterial Studies
sections.text:
Antibacterial activity and antibacterial properties of as-prepared PVA/ St/ Cs/ nZnO hydrogel membranes with various contents were tested by using E. coli, S. aureus and P. aeruginosa (Figures 9 and 10). After 6h incubation, E. coli, S. aureus and P. aeruginosa grew all over the hydrogel membrane while no growth was found in the area covered with hydrogel membranes. Among all studied samples, the PVA/St with 10%Cs and nZnO hydrogel
D ow

membrane sample performed the best with a circular zone of inhibition around the samples, and exhibited limited antibacterial activities.The obtained data revealed that hydrogel membranes having nZnO showed enhanced activity in comparison to the hydrogel without nZnO content. The antibacterial activity of hydrogel membranes was because of nZnO and chitosan, and the zinc ions released from the nZnO. The antibacterial mechanism of nZnO is through releasing final Zn+2 ions and destruction of proteins and lipids of bacterial cell wall membranes, and ultimately, the exudation of cell contents and bacterial cell death. As noticed in the figures, in hydrogel membranes, the positive charge in chitosan is produced by absorption of positive ions by free electron pair of nitrogen in NH2 group, and this issue allows chitosan to create a bond with all biological surfaces, like cell walls of bacteria, possessing negative charges; and cause the cell wall leakage leading to the death of bacteria.Ultimately, it can be understood that we can use nZnO particles in a polymer matrix to strengthen the antimicrobial activity of chitosan in wound dressing.

sections.heading: 3.7. Animal test
sections.text:
In a study on the wounds produced on rats treated with hydrogels based on polyvinyl alcohol / starch / chitosan with or without nZnO and control samples, Figure 11, in all cases, the weight of rats during 7 days dropped by 2-7% and then it gradually increased. This weight loss is due to severe metabolic, hormonal, immunological and circulatory damage resulting from the ulcers. Since energy is released to build new cells from energy reserves and proteins, this released energy reduces the weight of the rats during the first period of repair. This weight loss in humans in similar cases can exceed 150 grams per day.
3.8. Wound healing test
D ow

In each of the three groups, the size of the wound decreased from day three. Regarding Figures. 12, 13 and 14, wounds treated with hydrogel were recovered more rapidly than control samples. According to the images in Figure. 12, we can conclude that: Between days 0 and 3 in the control group, theeffects of wound healing were noticed; but in the second and third groups treated with hydrogel, the absorption exudative resulting from the inflammatory reaction prevented wound regeneration, and thus no recovery was achieved. Between days 3 and 7, in the wound treated by hydrogel, fibrin was homogeneously formed; while in wounds of control group, the fibrin was not formed homogeneously and uniformly.7 days after the operation, the control group showed hemorrhage while the hydrogel hardly induced hemorrhage. The healing rate on the 7 day in the control group was about 50% while in the second and third groups treated with hydrogel, it was about 10%; but between 7 and 14 days in the control group, healing had not started yet; while in the second and third groups, treated with hydrogel, the wound was well treated. Hydrogel generally passes through all stages of wound healing without disturbance. Since hydrogels can easily be removed from the surface of the wound in order to replace the dressing, they result in no further damage and do not interfere with the wound healing process. By contrast, there were no significant differences in wound size reduction between the hydrogel with and without nZnO. Thus, irrespective of the addition of nZnO, the PVA/St/Cs based hydrogel greatly improved wound healing. In the seventh day of microscopic examination, in the histocompatibility of thecontrol group with H & E staining, it was observed that the epidermis is still not completely formed, and there is still a scar and necrosis in a small part. At the level of ulcer, blood vessels are observed; on the other hand, granular tissues have a small number of lymphocytic D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7
inflammatory cells (Figures 15A, 17B).While in the tissue sections of the membrane group, hydrogel without nZnO, the epidermis has a full and extensive necrosis, the granulation tissue is about half the thickness of the skin, and the edema covers slightly another half of the thickness of the skin. A small amount of connective tissue is observed uniformly; and nephrotoxic inflammatory cells with lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophages are present (Figures 15B, 17D). In the study of tissue sections in the hydrogel membrane with nZnO group, it was observed that the epidermis is present in most parts of the necrosis and it is gradually being formed. The granulation tissue forms half of the skin thickness and the adipose tissue is being formed. Inflammatory cells that contain plasma cells, lymphocytes and neutrophils, and the connective tissue are gradually being formed, too (Figures 15C, 17F).
In the study of histological sections with H & E staining on day 14 and in the control group, it was observed that the epidermis has not been completely formed yet, and there is still a scar and necrosis in a small part. The granulation tissue is gone and the fibrous fibroblastic tissue is formed taking up half of the thickness of the skin. Edema is gone and there are a few inflammatory cells and many blood vessels. (Figures 16A, 17A) In the study of tissue sections in the hydrogel membrane group without nZnO, it was observed that the epidermis has a complete and extensive necrosis, the granulation tissue is about half the thickness of the skin, and edema is in the mild half of the thickness of the skin. A small amount of connective tissue is observed uniformly, and nephrotoxic inflammatory cells with lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophages are also present. Blood vessels decrease relative to the control sample, indicating entry into the regeneration phase. (Figures 16B, 17C) In the study of tissue sections in the group of hydrogel membranes with nZnO, it was observed that the epidermis was completely welded and there was no effect of necrosis, granulation and edema. On both sides of the wound, appendices of the dermal including hair D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2
2: 36
0 8
O ct
ob er
2 01
7
follicles were found and grew, and fat Hypoderm was being formed. However, in the middle of the wound, there was still fibrous connective tissue. The remaining inflammatory cells were low in number and were of lymphocyte type. The blood vessels decreased relative to the control sample, indicating entry into the regeneration phase. (Figures. 16C, 17E) With regard to reports, using water-based coatings called hydrogels that effectively keep the wound in place, act as a barrier to infection, help repair skin cells, and ultimately improve wound healing is recommended. The porous hydrogels create strong scaffolds that allow new cells to colonize and begin to create new tissues. They also strengthen the angioplasty to provide food and improve wound healing faster. On the other hand, these porous networks allow free entry of cells into and their exit out of the scaffold without causing any damage to it. Hydrogel has even partially stimulated the formation of hair follicles and lipid glands.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In this paper, a novel synthesized hydrogel membrane was successfully prepared from immobilization of the nZnO powder onto the PVA/St/Cs polymer hydrogel membrane. The following results were deduced from this investigation:
 The capacity of swelling of hydrogel membranes has been studied. Higher bond in the
hydrogel membranes limits the diffusion of water for the swelling. The presence of nZnO causes a decrease in all pores.
 With an increase in chitosan percentage, the tensile strength was decreased; while by
adding nZnO, the tensile strength was increased.
 With an increase in the amount of chitosan, the rate of water vapor transmission
increases.
D ow

de d
by [
G ot
he nb
ur g

ve rs
ity L
ib ra
ry ]
at 2
2: 36
0 8

ob er
2 01
7
 SEM imaging showed that chitosan could decrease the network densities. In addition,
adding nZnO causes a reduction in the porosity of hydrogel membranes.
 The viability of the cell reached above 87%, which indicated that PVA/St/Cs/nZnO
hydrogel membrane extracts have extremely low toxicity on L929 fibroblast cells.
 The PVA/St with 10%Cs and nZnO hydrogel membranes performed the best antibacterial
activity.
 On the 14thday, the wound healing treatment in hydrogel without nZnO was 95% and the
wound treated in hydrogel with nZnO was 96%, while the percentage of wound healing in the control group was 79%.

referenceMentions.context: An ideal wound dressing should have flexibility, adequate mechanical strength, and tear resistance; moreover, it should not stick onto the wounds [2], and should also be able to absorb wound exudates from the wound surface [3].

An ideal wound dressing should have flexibility, adequate mechanical strength, and tear resistance; moreover, it should not stick onto the wounds [2], and should also be able to absorb wound exudates from the wound surface [3].
The dressing should not only serve as a barrier against microbes, but it shouldalso prevent the growth of microorganisms on the wound surface [4].
In addition, it should be porous in nature so that it can easily let the gaseous exchange in and out of the wound surface [3].
Most of them have had good effects on normal wound healing; however, their effects on chronic or diabetic foot ulcers have not been studied yet [6, 7].
Most of them have had good effects on normal wound healing; however, their effects on chronic or diabetic foot ulcers have not been studied yet [6, 7].
Moreover, they do not generallyhave adequate mechanical strength and flexibility [8], some of them lack blood-clotting ability and some have no or little antibacterial activity.
With regard to all these factors, it is necessary to develop a wound dressing material that has all the ideal requirements [9].

PVA hydrogels have already been used for a large number of pharmaceutical and biomedical applications [10]because apart from their ease of processing, their advantages such as biocompatibility, non-carcinogenicity, bio-adhesiveness, nonD ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7

At the same time, PVA gels have a high degree of swelling in water or biological fluids in addition to an elastic or rubbery nature [11], which makes it capable of simulating natural tissues and which can be suitably accepted in the body.
This method is regarded as the best and the preferred one for obtaining physically crosslinked PVA hydrogel without using traditional toxic chemical crosslinking agents [12].

metadata.abstractText: In this work, hydrogel membranes were developed based on poly vinyl alcohol (PVA), starch (St), and chitosan (Cs) hydrogels with nano Zinc oxide (nZnO). PVA/St/Cs/nZnO hydrogel membranes were prepared by freezing-thawing cycles, and the aqueous PVA/St solutions were prepared by dissolving PVA in distilled water. After the dissolution of PVA, starch was mixed, and the mixture was stirred. Then, chitosan powder was added into acetic acid, and the mixture was stirred to form a chitosan solution. Subsequently, Cs, St and PVA solutions were blended together to form a homogeneous PVA/St/Cs ternary blend solution.Measurement of Equilibrium Swelling Ratio (ESR),Water Vapor Transmission Test (WVTR), mechanical properties, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), MTT [3-(4, 5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2, 5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide] assay, D ow nl oa de d by [ G ot he nb ur g U ni ve rs ity L ib ra ry ] at 2 2: 36 0 8 O ct ob er 2 01 7 antibacterial studies, in vivo wound healing effect and histopathology of the hydrogel membranes were then performed. The examination revealed that the hydrogel membranes were more effective as a wound dressing in the early stages of wound healing and that the gel could be used in topic applications requiring a large spectrum of antibacterial activity; namely, as a bandage for wound dressing.
